## Overview

This R Markdown script builds the HRS Stress Dataset for allostatic (over)load research using self-reported stress measures from the [Health and Retirement Study (HRS)](https://hrs.isr.umich.edu/).  

‚ö†Ô∏è Before continuing, ensure your data are downloaded and organized as described in [`HRS_stress_access_guide.md`](https://github.com/CHORDSLab/HRS-Stress-Measures-and-Supplementary-Datasets/blob/main/HRS_stress/HRS_stress_access_guide.md).  

For a full overview of variables, see [`HRS_Stress_Data_Overview.pdf`](https://github.com/CHORDSLab/HRS-Stress-Measures-and-Supplementary-Datasets/blob/main/HRS_stress/HRS_Stress_Data_Overview.pdf).  

A user guide for the Psychosocial and Lifestyle Questionnaire (2006‚Äì2022) is available here: [HRS 2006‚Äì2022 SAQ User Guide (PDF)](https://hrs.isr.umich.edu/sites/default/files/biblio/HRS%202006-2022%20SAQ%20User%20Guide.pdf).  


---

## Build Modes (Read Me First)  

There are two ways to use this script, depending on whether you want to build a **single-year** or **longitudinal** version of the HRS Stress dataset.  

---

### Option A. Single-Year Build  
Use this mode if you only downloaded **one** HRS Core wave (e.g., 2016).  

**Steps:**  
1. Run the following chunks:  
   - `Setup & Libraries`  
   - `Set File Path`  
   - the `Load and clean [YEAR]` chunk for your chosen year    
2. (Optional) Run the ‚ÄúSave [YEAR]-only dataset‚Äù chunk right below it.    
3. Stop here ‚Äî you do **not** need to combine other years.  

üí° *Example:* If you downloaded only the 2016 Core data, scroll down to the ‚ÄúLoad and clean 2016‚Äù section and run those chunks.  

---

### Option B. Longitudinal Build (2006‚Äì2022)  
Use this mode if you downloaded **all HRS Core waves** from 2006‚Äì2022.  

**Steps:**  
1. Run every chunk in order, from top to bottom:  
   - `Setup & Libraries`  
   - `Step 1. Set File Path`  
   - all `Step 2. Load and clean [YEAR]` chunks (2006‚Äì2022)  
   - `Step 3. Combine All Years (Longitudinal Build Only)`  
   - `Step 4. Save and Export Longitudinal Dataset`  
2. This will create a single combined dataset named `full_hrs_stress`.  

üí° *Partial build:* You can also build a smaller panel (e.g., 2014‚Äì2022) by running only the chunks for those specific years, then running the combine step.  


---

### What You‚Äôll Need to Run This Script  

- Raw HRS data, organized as described in the guide  
- R environment with the following packages: `SAScii`, `dplyr`, `stringr`  
- Familiarity with HRS data formats and .sas scripts  


## Setup & Libraries  

```{r install-packages, eval=FALSE}
install.packages(c("SAScii", "dplyr", "stringr"))
```

```{r libraries}
library(SAScii)
library(dplyr)
library(stringr)
```

---

## üìÅ Set File Path  

```{r file-path}
# Set to the location of your "HRS Data Products" folder
path <- "../path_to_your_folder/HRS Data Products/HRS Core Data" # Replace with the full path to your local "HRS Data Products" folder
```



---

### Load and clean 2006 HRS Core (LB) data *(run for 2006 builds or longitudinal builds)*

```{r}

#####################
# Load and clean 2006 HRS Core (LBQ) data
# Run this chunk if you need 2006 (either single-year OR longitudinal)
#####################

# Navigate to the HRS Core Data folder
setwd(file.path(path, "h06core"))

# Load 2006 Leave-Behind Questionnaire (LBQ)
core_2006 <- read.SAScii(
  "h06da/H06LB_R.da",
  "h06sas/H06LB_R.sas"
)

# Add unique identifier (HHID + PN)
add_id <- function(df) df %>% mutate(unique_id = paste(HHID, PN, sep = "_"))
core_2006 <- add_id(core_2006)

clean_2006 <- core_2006 %>%
  transmute(
    unique_id,
    survey_year = 2006L,
    id_year = paste(unique_id, survey_year, sep = "_"),

    # End-of-Month Financial Strain
    eomfs   = KLB039B,

    # Ongoing Chronic Stressors (A1‚ÄìA8)
    ocs_01  = KLB040A,
    ocs_02  = KLB040B,
    ocs_03  = KLB040C,
    ocs_04  = KLB040D,
    ocs_05  = KLB040E,
    ocs_06  = KLB040F,
    ocs_07  = KLB040G,
    ocs_08  = KLB040H,

    # Stressful Life Events (last 5 years) + year follow-ups
    sle_01  = KLB038A,   # job loss
    sle_02  = KLB038AY,  # job loss year
    sle_03  = KLB038B,   # unemployed self
    sle_04  = KLB038BY,  # unemployed self year
    sle_05  = KLB038C,   # other unemployed
    sle_06  = KLB038CY,  # other unemployed year
    sle_07  = KLB038D,   # moved to worse residence
    sle_08  = KLB038DY,  # moved year
    sle_09  = KLB038E,   # robbed/burglarized
    sle_10  = KLB038EY   # robbed/burglarized year
    # Note: 2006 has no fraud items (sle_11 / sle_12)
  )

# Preview the cleaned 2006 data
glimpse(clean_2006)

```

### Optional: Save 2006-only dataset

```{r}
# Run this if you're only building 2006 and not doing longitudinal

write.csv(clean_2006, "HRS_Stress_2006.csv", row.names = FALSE)
saveRDS(clean_2006, "HRS_Stress_2006.rds")

```

### Combine All Years (Run Only for Longitudinal Build)

```{r}

# NOTE:
# - This step combines all the yearly "clean_[year]" datasets that you created above.
# - If you only built certain years (e.g., 2014‚Äì2022), remove any years from the
#   "clean_list" below that you did not load or clean.
#   Example:
#     clean_list <- list(clean_2014, clean_2016, clean_2018, clean_2020, clean_2022)
#
# The bind_rows() function will automatically align columns and fill in missing
# variables with NA where necessary.

library(dplyr)

# Collect all cleaned waves
clean_list <- list(
  clean_2006, clean_2008, clean_2010, clean_2012, clean_2014,
  clean_2016, clean_2018, clean_2020, clean_2022
)

# Join all years by stacking (fills missing cols with NA automatically)
full_hrs_stress <- bind_rows(clean_list) %>%
  arrange(id_year) %>%
  relocate(id_year, .before = 1) # move id_year to first column

# Preview the full data
glimpse(full_hrs_stress)

```


---

### Save and Export Longitudinal Dataset (2006‚Äì2022 Only)


Export the cleaned dataset for future use in your preferred format. Below are examples using both `write.csv()` and `saveRDS()`: 

```{r}

# Save longitudinal dataset (2006‚Äì2022)
write.csv(full_hrs_stress, "HRS_Stress_Longitudinal_2006_2022.csv", row.names = FALSE)
saveRDS(full_hrs_stress, "HRS_Stress_Longitudinal_2006_2022.rds")

```

### Optional: Merge your HRS Stress dataset with your main HRS Allostatic (over)Load dataset

If you‚Äôve already built the **HRS Allostatic (over)Load dataset** (from HRS_dataset_construction.Rmd), you can merge it with your **HRS Stress** dataset ‚Äî whether you built a *single-year* or *longitudinal* version.  

**Instructions:**
